newsitem.title: UK: UK MP reintroduces bill on computer millennium bug.
newsitem.headline: UK MP reintroduces bill on computer millennium bug.

text.p: A Conservative member of parliament launched a new effort on Tuesday to force British firms to face up to the threat of a "millennium meltdown" of their computers.

David Atkinson won permission after a brief debate in the House of Commons to re-introduce a bill that would require companies to assess whether their computers are capable of recognising the year 2000 and to propose a plan of action if necessary.

Atkinson told Reuters he would seek a meeting with junior trade and industry minister John Battle in the new Labour government to lobby for his bill. Without government support, it has no chance of becoming law.
It is Atkinson's second attempt to legislate on the issue. The previous Conservative government scuppered the first attempt in February, saying it would impose costly burdens on business.
Atkinson told parliament that a failure to make sure computer programmes can properly identify calendar dates after 31 December 1999 could lead to the costliest burden of all -- bankruptcy.

Payroll systems could collapse, financial and invoicing records could be lost and myriad computer-controlled machines could go haywire if they are flummoxed by a double-zero representing the start of the year 2000, he said.
The result, Atkinson said, would be a catastrophe.

"Far from imposing new burdens on business, the bill merely clarifies for company directors and their auditors an existing duty to give shareholders a true and fair assessment of the company as a going concern in the forseeable future."
